data.text: Contents
Introduction

A fall may be defined as “an event which causes a person to unintentionally rest on the ground or other lower level” (NICE, 2019). It is distinct from a medical collapse which may be caused by an acute medical problem, such as an acute arrhythmia, transient ischaemic attack etc.
Falls are the most commonly reported patient safety incident in the acute hospital setting (RCP, 2015) with in excess of 250,000 falls reported annually (NRLS).

Whilst most falls do not lead to significant harm, in 2018 nearly 4% of all hip fractures in England and Wales occurred in people who were hospital inpatients (RCP, 2020). There were also a significant number of head injuries which may lead to permanent disability or death. This may be more common in frail patients and those on anticoagulant therapies.

Falls become more common as we age with 1:3 over the age of 65 falling per year rising to 1:2 of those over 85 years. In addition, older people are more likely to suffer significant injury if they do fall; for example fractures are more common due to reduced bone density associated with aging.

The national audit of in patient falls noted that whilst hip fractures are most likely to occur in the “oldest of the old” and the “frailest of the frail,” however only 21% of falls occurred on elderly care wards. This highlights the need for all specialities and areas of the hospital caring for older people to be aware of local falls policies, protocols and guidelines.
Scope
This policy applies to patients over the age of 16 admitted to adult inpatient areas of Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (‘the Trust'). Exclusions include:
Outpatient areas
Paediatric patients
The purpose of this document is to:
To provide a framework for the identification and management of falls risk in adult in patients cared for within Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust
To define the roles and responsibilities of staff with regard to Falls prevention and Management of Adult Inpatients
To describe the process for Post Falls Assessment and monitoring with regard to potential injury

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust

The Harm Free Care Falls Panel have the responsibility of reviewing all falls leading to moderate or above levels of harm and escalating to the Executive review Group if they require consideration for declaration as a Serious incident. (SI).

Chief Nursing Officer and Chief Medical Officer have a responsibility to promote safe practice and facilitate the medical input into reviewing incidents. They are responsible for ensuring processes are in place to manage the risks associated with slips, trips and falls.

Director and Associate Director for Harm Free Care are responsible for ensuring policies and procedures are in place for the prevention and management of falls. To ensure that falls with injury are appropriately investigated and lessons learnt effectively disseminated across the Trust.
Clinical lead for Falls is responsible forDeveloping Falls prevention and management policies and protocols
Monitoring the number and severity of falls and injuries sustained in inpatient falls
Identifying areas for improvement across the Trust
Collating falls data from across the sites and identifying themes, trends and areas for service improvement
Collating falls data for reporting as required
Co-ordinating falls improvement programs and leading in National and Local
Audit programmes
Falls Improvement Specialist nurses
Contributing to the development of falls prevention and management policies and protocols.
Providing specialist advice regarding the prevention and management of in patient falls including patients with complex needs
Participating in National and Local audit and Quality Improvement Programmes
Following up patients who have had an inpatient fall to ensure that they are being managed optimally with regard to their falls risk and post falls monitoring/treatment.
Supporting Staff to learn from falls and develop falls prevention strategies for their patients
Contributing to Root Cause Analysis investigations and attending Harm Free Care Panels.
Providing accurate site data for governance and reporting
Providing education regarding falls and falls policy and guidelines
Heads of nursing, Matrons, Clinical Leads, Ward Managers
Staff within their areas are aware of the policy and their duties within it
Monitor compliance with mandatory training
Registered Nursing Staff are responsible:
For ensuring patients under their care have been assessed appropriately for falls risk and have suitable mitigation in place
Are familiar with the assessment and management of patients who fall whilst in hospital
Are competent and confident to complete and interpret Neurological Observations, including the correct and accurate use of the Glasgow Coma Scale
for escalating concerns regarding deterioration following an inpatient fall e.g. deteriorating GCS or delays in assessment, including delays in imaging
Health Care Support workers:
Knowing which of their patients are at risk of falls and the reasons for that risk
Escalating any concerns regarding changes in their patients which might increase their falls risk
Being aware of the post fall protocol and the need to ensure that patients are cleared of acute injury prior to attempting to get them up
Doctors are responsible for:
Considering Falls risk in assessment and treatment plans
Being aware of medications that may increase the risk of falling and considering this in prescribing decisions
Responding promptly to requests to review patients following inpatient falls and
within 30 minutes if significant injury is suspected
Requesting any indicated imaging and investigations to rule out acute injury urgently and discussing and agreeing with the radiologist
Ensuring images and investigations requested post fall are followed up and acted upon in a reasonable timeframe
Seeking Senior or Specialist opinion where the presence or absence of injury following a fall may be ambiguous
In the case of significant head injury, escalating to the Tertiary centre for advice as appropriate
All staff working in clinical areas
Are responsible for providing safe patient care and must work within Trust policies, protocols and guidelines including
MSEPO - 19021 Managing Risk of Slip Trip Fall incidents
Falls Risk Assessment:

Falls assessment for Adult Inpatients must be completed within 12 hours of admission. Any obvious immediate risk (such as risky behaviours) should be mitigated as a matter of urgency and not dependant on the completion of the full assessment (for example patients requiring Enhanced Supervision due to risky behaviours).
Patients who require a Falls care Plan:
Those aged 65 and over
Those aged 50-64 with conditions that put them at an increased risk of fall
Patients fitting the above criteria (5.2) must have a multifactorial risk assessment completed
The assessment must be reviewed and where necessary updated, on ward moves, with any significant change in the patients' condition, after any inpatient fall and at a minimum weekly.

For patients at risk of falls through risky behaviours such as walking without insight into their unsteadiness and falls risk, consideration must be made for the requirement for enhanced levels of supervision. Please refer to the Enhanced Supervision Policy (or equivalent). It is recognised that even with 1:1 supervision not all falls can be prevented. Prevention would be determined by the ability of staff to dissuade or distract from risky behaviours. This may not be possible in patients showing agitation and aggression.
The falling patient

Once a patient starts to fall, staff are limited in their ability to intervene safely in a manner that would not put themselves of the patient at increased risk. The Moving and Handling Adviser is not able to advise that staff attempt to control or prevent the descent of a falling patient. Please refer to the Moving and Handling policy (or equivalent).
Post falls assessment and management

Whilst most in patient falls do not lead to significant harm, it is important that patients are assessed for injury prior to retrieval from the fall and that any suspected injury is managed appropriately and within acceptable timeframes.

It is important to note that the severity of the injury sustained is often a consequence of the frailty of the patient and not necessarily dependant on a fall with great impact. Special care must be taken when excluding serious injury in the Frail Elderly or those with dementia/delirium who may present atypically.

Analysis of patient safety incidents reported to the National Reporting and Learning System (in the 12 months prior to 25 March 2010) indicated that around 200 patients with fractures or intracranial injury after a fall in hospital experienced some failure of aftercare.

Problems included: delayed diagnosis of fractures (ranging from several hours to several days after the fall) neurological observations not recorded at all or recorded at inadequate intervals resulting in delayed diagnosis of intracranial bleeding; sling hoists used to move patients despite signs or symptoms of limb fracture or spinal injury; delays in access to urgent investigations or surgery.
Patients who fall in hospitals can expect treatment equal to that they would receive if they presented similarly to the Emergency Department in terms of quality and timings.
Exclusion of significant medical event/collapse/cardiac arrest:
Initial assessment should focus on the exclusion of a medical emergency such as peri- or cardiac arrest and if this is suspected staff should follow the Resuscitation policy and guidelines.
Suspected Spinal Injury:

Before retrieval from the floor the patient must be cleared for suspected spinal injury which may present as central spinal pain, new altered sensation in the arms or legs. If spinal injury is suspected then the patient must suitably be immobilised prior to flat lifting from the floor. This must only be done by staff with the appropriate skills and may require a Trauma Call. Whilst awaiting specialist assistance staff should attempt to keep the patient calm and still.
Hip fracture:

Hip fracture may present as pain in the hip, groin or knee areas, shortening and external rotation of the leg, inability to lift the leg from the floor from the hip and tenderness on palpation of the joint.

Where hip fracture is suspected the patient must be flat lifted from the floor using appropriate manual handling equipment and techniques (Please refer to the Manual Handling Policy). Analgesia should be considered prior to moving the patient.
Head Injury:

In patients with confirmed head injury or where head injury cannot be excluded (for example where a confused patient has had an unwitnessed fall) Neurological observations (Glasgow Coma Scale and physiological observations) must be completed by a qualified Registered Nurse competent in neurological observations.
Neurological observations must be completed as per NICE Guideline CG 176.

Perform and record observations on a half-hourly basis until GCS equal to  has been achieved (baseline may be 14/15 for patients with confusion). The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to  should be as follows:
Half-hourly for 2 hours
Then 1-hourly for 4 hours
Then 2-hourly for 6 hours then medical review
Any of the following examples of neurological deterioration should prompt urgent reappraisal by the supervising doctor:
Development of agitation or abnormal behaviour.
A sustained (that is, for at least 30 minutes) drop of 1 point in GCS score (greater weight should be given to a drop of 1 point in the motor response score of the GCS).
Any drop of 3 or more points in the eye-opening or verbal response scores of the GCS, or 2 or more points in the motor response score.
Development of severe or increasing headache or persisting vomiting.
New or evolving neurological symptoms or signs such as pupil inequality or asymmetry of limb or facial movement

For patients who have sustained a head injury with no other indications for a CT head scan and who are having anticoagulant treatment, it may be necessary to perform a CT head scan within 8 hours of the injury (NICE, CG176). The decision should be made after discussion with a Senior Clinician and the rationale recorded in the clinical record. A provisional written radiology report should be made available within 1 hour of the scan being performed.

For other potential fractures such as wrist, humeral or clavicle fractures the site should be supported and analgesia considered prior to assisting the patient from the floor using the most appropriate method and/or equipment. Lower limb fractures other than hip fracture may also require flat retrieval (e.g. Hoverjack or flat hoist) to ensure patient and staff safety. Please refer to the Moving and Handling Policy (or equivalent)
Escalation for medical review:

Urgent, within 30 minutes: Loss of consciousness, evidence of spinal injury, significant head injury, evidence of a fracture, deteriorating GCS during monitoring period or other significant clinical concern
Imaging:
Any imaging to exclude significant injury such as fracture or head injury must be requested as urgent and discussed with the Radiologist;
Imaging should be completed, reviewed and acted upon promptly.
Reporting requirements

All fall incidents and near misses must be reported through the DATIX system with details of the circumstances of the fall and any resulting injury. Care must be taken to grade the injury severity correctly (refer to the Incident Reporting Policy or equivalent).
Datix reports should include wherever possible:
The patients account of events
The position the patient was found within the room or corridor
Any witness account (without using names)
If relevant (i.e. fall from the bed) – the position of the bed rail at the time of the fall and whether this was as assessed
Falls with harm of moderate severity or above will require further investigation – please refer to the Procedure for the Reporting and Management of Incidents and Serious Incidents MSEPO-19015

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the DoN and DDoN meeting members, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local DoN and DDoN meeting members documents. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the DoN and DDoN meeting membersof the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
